author: Conor Duffy
title: Trump supporters hailing immigration order
text:
Donald Trump's executive order on immigration and its immediate consequences explained. 
In the historic town of Fredericksburgin Virginia, a group of local tea party supporters have gathered at the local pool hall to celebrate the new presidency. 
These Trump supporters say the new President will deliver on all his promises, a move that is likely to trigger more international outrage. Trump's orders 'about putting Americans first' 
Dale Swanson runs firearms classes for conservative women as well as chairing a local tea party group. Photo: Dale Swanson teaches local women firearm safety. (ABC News: Brad Fulton) 
"Well I think Trump's doing exactly what we wanted him to do. I'm very grateful that we finally have a president in America that loves America and wants to protect American citizens first," Ms Swanson says. 
"It's very necessary because we don't want to happen to America what's happening over in Europe and Germany and we don't want our women to be killed and raped." 
Ms Swanson says Mr Trump and his controversial executive orders are "amazing". 
"If you can't come into America and respect our constitution and our republic then you need to go somewhere else." 
Michael Hirsch runs another local tea party group. 
Less than 2 per cent of Virginia's 8 million residents identify as Muslim, but Mr Hirsch and his friends feel threatened. 
Mr Hirsch has lived in Fredericksburg for over 30 years. 
Like his friends at the pool hall, he fears the introduction of sharia law, which is banned in some US states. 
"I think it was Samuel Adams that said: 'if a religion is subversive to the constitution then it should not be afforded these protections like the first amendment,' Mr Hirsch says. 
"So when you look at the Islamic philosophy — if you want to call it that — if you want to elevate sharia above the constitution, how can it have a constitutional protection?"
